description.narrative: Support to Protection and Promotion of the Rights of Indigenous Peoples - Indigenous peoples’ rights, including collective rights to land, territories and natural resources are promoted, respected and protected. Outcome: Indigenous peoples (including indigenous women) exercise their rights, including collective rights to land, territories and natural resources. Output 1: Indigenous peoples contribute to and claim their rights in climate action. Output 2: Indigenous peoples in 5 selected countries claim their right to land, territories and natural resources. Output 3: Indigenous peoples have taken steps to exercise self governance. Output 4: Indigenous peoples and IWGIA engage with international and regional human rights mechanisms and use their recommendations at national level.

participating-org.narrative: International Work Group for Indigenous Affairs

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Indigenous peoples contribute to and claim their rights in climate action.

1.1) Indigenous peoples contribute to and claim their rights in climate action.
1.2) % of approved Green Climate Fund (GCF) projects complying with the GCF Indigenous Peoples' Policy in 2 selected countries (Nepal &Tanzania).
Indigenous peoples in 5 selected countries claim their rights to land, territories and natural resources.

2.1) No. of land rights violations protested by IWGIA partners (Kenya, Tanzania, Nepal, India, Bangladesh)
2.2) No. of actions IWGIA’s partners take to achieve land tenure security (Kenya Tanzania, Nepal, India, Bangladesh)

actual.value:
2.1) 25 - in 2021, 10 land rights violations were protested in Tanzania, 1 in Kenya, 12 in Nepal, 1 Bangladesh and 2 in India.
2.2) 5 - in 2021, 3 actions to achieve land tenure security were taken by indigenous peoples in Nepal, 1 in Kenya and 1 in Bangladesh.

title.narrative: Indigenous peoples have taken steps to exercise self-governance.

3.1) No of indigenous peoples reaching agreements on their status as self-governing territories with national authorities (Bolivia & Peru)
3.2) No. of IWGIA’s partners developing and/or implementing a strategy for the recognition & management of their territories (Bolivia & Kenya)

actual.value:
3.1) 3 - In 2021, IWGIA supported 3 autonomous indigenous governments: the Awajun & the Wampis in Peru, the Charagua in Bolivia. But not all of them have been recognised by the national authorities as per indicator.
3.2) In process - In 2021, IWGIA’s partners have been developing a strategy for therecognition and management of their territories in Bolivia.

title.narrative: Indigenous peoples and IWGIA engage with international and regional human rights mechanisms and use their recommendations at national level.

4.1) No. of indigenous representatives engaging in and contributing to international (UNFPII, UNSRIP, EMRIP, HRC, UNGPs CSW/Beijing+25, SDG/HLPF) and regional (ACHPR, IACHR) mechanisms with documentation and advocacy.
4.2) No. of actions at national level, IWGIA partners take to provide input to international and regional mechanisms and follow up on the recommendations issued by international and regional mechanisms.
4.3) No. articles/page hits on IWGIA’s website of the yearbook The Indigenous World in Spanish and in English

actual.value:
4.1) 574 - In 2021, 574 Indigenous Peoples representatives and relevant stakeholders (such as members of international and regional mechanisms and experts) engaged and contributed to international and regional mechanisms with documentation and advocacy.
4.2) 6 - In 2021, IWGIA partners took 6 actions at national level (in Peru, Bolivia, Russia, Tanzania, Nepal and India) to provide input to international and regional mechanisms and follow up on the recommendations issued by international and a regional mechanisms.
4.3) 105,735 - In 2021, articles and pages from the Indigenous World have been hit 47.655 times for the English version and 58.080 times for the Spanish version.

title.narrative: Indigenous peoples (including indigenous women) exercise their rights, including collective rights to land, territories and natural resources (Nepal, Bangladesh, India, Tanzania, Kenya, Peru, Bolivia).

No. of concrete changes that protect indigenous peoples’ rights to land, territories, natural resources at:
1) Local level (land titles, self-governance recognition, indigenous led climate actions, actions led by women, action led by youth)
2) National level (policies, legislations, commitments, court decisions, implementation of international rulings/recommendations)
3) International level (policies, platforms, commitments, funding, projects, rulings)
